description.narrative:
The overarching objective of the intervention is: National social protection policies and programmes utilize a stronger evidence base on social cash transfers to reduce poverty, promote equitable development and improve children's and their families well-being and livelihoods in different countries.
The four intermediate objectives that will contribute to this objective are:
- Support to national longitudinal quantitative and qualitative impact evaluation of government owned and implemented cash transfer programmes in the region - to understand programme impacts and pathways through which these impacts are achieved.
- Support to longitudinal quantitative and qualitative impact evaluations of emerging social protection initiatives related to cash plus programming and cash in humanitarian settings.
- Country-level and cross-regional analysis to draw thematic and operational lessons based on the diversity of social transfer programmes in the region.
- Facilitate mechanisms for learning and exchange among regional policy-makers, implementers, researchers and civil society - through workshops, web resources, public data availability and open-access publications.

Innocenti, the research institute of UNICEF has applied for 21MSEK to implement Transfer Project phase 2, 2018-2020. The project shall contribute to longitudinal quantitative and qualitatve evaluations of the effects of social protection systems with cash transfers in government led programs for social cash transfers. The project shall especially evaluate new initiatives to strengthen the effects of social cash transfer through complementary contributions, so called 'Cash Plus', and contribute to evaluation of cash support in humanitarian aid.
The Transfer project undertakes analysis within countries but also regional analysis with the purpose of drawing thematic conclusions and to draw conclusions of differences in implementation and effects of different types of social cash transfer programs in the region.
The project also aims to contribute to learning and exchange between policy-makers, implementing agencies, researchers and civil society through seminars, web-based information, publication of data and open-source publications. The Transfer project is focused on strengthening monitoring and evaluation of government led programmes for social cash transfer and through evidence-based information strengthen programme design and policy dialogue. The research is also expected to contribute to knowledge about the link between social protection and cash transfers in humanitarian contexts. The project also aims to strengthen research capacity in Africa for studying and evaluating social protection systems. The Transfer project is implemented in coperation with governments, implementing agencies responsible for social protection programmes, and in cooperation with local researchers with the aim to strengthen ownership and knowledge locally. The total budget of the project is 4,385,741 USD of which Sida contributes with 21 million SEK (approximately 2,617,662 USD).

UNICEFs forskningsinstitut Innocenti har ansökt om 21 miljoner SEK för att genomföra Transfer Project 2. Projektet ska bidra till långsiktiga kvantitativa och kvalitativa utvärderingar av effekterna av sociala trygghetssystem med kontantstöd i statliga program för sociala kontantstöd. Projektet ska särskilt utvärdera nya initiativ för att stärka effekterna av sociala kontantstöd genom kompletterande insatser, så kallat "Cash Plus", samt bidra till utvärdering av kontantstöd inom humanitärt bistånd.
Transfer projektet gör analys inom länder men gör även regionala analyser i syfte att dra tematiska slutsatser och för att dra slutsatser om skillnader i genomförande och effekter av olika sociala kontantstödsprogram i regionen.
Projektet syftar dessutom till att bidra till lärande och utbyte mellan beslutsfattare, genomförare, forskare och civila samhället genom seminarier, webb-baserad information, publicering av data och öppet tillgängliga publikationer.
Transfer projektet är inriktat på att stärka uppföljning och utvärdering av statliga ledda program för sociala trygghetssystem och bidra till att genom evidensbaserad kunskap stärka programmering och policydialog om programmens genomförande. Forskningen förväntas också bidra till att stärka kunskap om länken mellan social trygghet och kontantstöd i humanitärt bistånd. Transfer projektet genomförs i samarbete med regeringar, genomförande myndigheter som ansvarar för program för social trygghet samt i samarbete med lokala forskare, i syfte att stärka ägarskap och kunskap lokalt. Projektet förväntas också stärka Sidas samarbete inom sociala trygghetssystem genom att dialog om inriktning och genomförande kan baseras på evidens från kvalitativ forskning och utvärdering.
Projektets totala budget är 4,385,741 USD varav Sida bidrar med 21 miljoner SEK (cirka 2,617,662 USD).

sector.narrative: Social protection and welfare services policy, planning and administration

tag.narrative: 1.3 - Implement nationally appropriate social protection systems and measures for all, including floors, and by 2030 achieve substantial coverage of the poor and the vulnerable.
1.3 - Införa nationellt lämpliga system och åtgärder för socialt skydd för alla, inklusive grundskydd, och senast 2030 säkerställa att de omfattar en väsentlig andel av de fattiga och de utsatta.
10.4 - Adopt policies, especially fiscal, wage and social protection policies, and progressively achieve greater equality.
10.4 - Besluta om politik, särskilt finans-, löne- och socialskyddspolitik, och successivt uppnå ökad jämlikhet.
16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.
16.6 - Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.

5.4 - Erkänna och värdesätta obetalt omsorgs- och hushållsarbete genom att tillhandahålla offentliga tjänster, infrastruktur och socialt skydd samt genom att främja delat ansvar inom hushållet och familjen, i enlighet med vad som är nationellt lämpligt.

5.4 - Recognize and value unpaid care and domestic work through the provision of public services, infrastructure and social protection policies and the promotion of shared responsibility within the household and the family as nationally appropriate.
8.5 - By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.

8.5 - Senast 2030 uppnå full och produktiv sysselsättning med anständiga arbetsvillkor för alla kvinnor och män, inklusive ungdomar och personer med funktionsnedsättning, samt lika lön för likvärdigt arbete.

description.narrative:
The Conclusion on performance is prepared based on the Progress Report including a financial statement for 2020 received in June 2021 and an Audited statement received in September 2021, an Annual meeting was held virtually in July 2021, as a meeting in person between Sida and Innocenti could not be implemented due to lock down measures in Italy after the outbreak of COVID-19.
In 2020 the Transfer project has continued to provide evidence to national governments on Social Cash Transfers and to stakeholders within the field of social protection. The Transfer project has synthesized cross-country findings; continued ongoing research projects and initiated new research on cash plus (systems linkages); research also includes the area of social protection in contexts of fragility and forced displacement. The Transfer Project has undertaken research and supported capacity building and dissemination of evidence according to plan though with minor delays in 2020 due to the pandemic. The research is of high quality and internationally recognised as providing important knowledge and evidence on the effects of social protection and cash transfers. This evidence is important for governments in partner countries that are expanding social protection systems which require substantial and long-term investments. The Transfer project also has direct linkages to Sida-supported projects in social protection.
In 2020, the Transfer project provided technical support to the following government run impact evaluation research cash plus programmes: - Burkina Faso Child Grant Programme (data collection, analysis, report and manuscript drafting.) - Ethiopia Integrated Safety Net Programme separate impact evaluations in 1) Amhara and 2) Addis and other urban settings (data collection, analysis, report and manuscript drafting). - Mozambique Child Grant Programme (analysis, process evaluation and manuscript drafting) - Tanzania Adolescent Cash Plus Pilot (analysis and manuscript drafting)
Significant achievements included: the completion of a baseline data collection in Burkina Faso in a challenging context, additional qualitative data collection round in Ethiopia, finalizing work on strategies to optimize the responsiveness of the Malawi SCT to lifecycle and education needs, and timely thought leadership with blogs and briefs on the impacts of COVID-19 on child labour, gender-based violence and the role of social protection (including its gender sensitivity) in addressing these consequences. The project aims at uptake by national governments and the team disseminated evidence to government and stakeholders through four in-country workshops. Innocenti researchers participated in these workshops remotely due to COVID-19 related travel restrictions: 1. Ethiopia. Child Marriage and Ethiopia's Productive Safety Net Programme (PSNP): Analysis of protective Pathways in Amhara Region". 2. Tanzania. Adolescent Cash Plus Evaluation Team Meeting. Presentation of Round 3 findings and Discussion for Planned Round 4. 3. Mozambique. "Resultados da Avaliação de Impacto do Subsidio para Crianças dos 0 a 2 anos em Moçambique: Linha de Base" (Results of the Impact Evaluation of the Child Grant 0-2 in Mozambique: Baseline) 4. Malawi. Policy options to improve education and address lifecycle vulnerabilities among beneficiaries of the Malawi Cash Transfer Programme. In addition, UNICEF Innocenti researchers presented nine times at academic conferences, international workshops and roundtables and published eight peer-reviewed journal articles.
The Transfer Project has an increasing online audience and social media presence, as well as an improved website. Below are some of the key figures The primary social media channel of the Transfer Project is Twitter (@TransferProjct). Followers include academics, researchers, policymakers, UN staff and development partners. Twitter: - 3,095 followers, 20.9% increase compared to last year. - 527,200 impressions (i.e. number of times the posts were seen) - The audience is highly engaged with a 1.75% engagement rate (industry average for non-profit sector is 0.062). Slide Share: - 78 presentations are available on the Transfer Project Slide Share account. - Over the year, presentations have been viewed 20,000 times. Newsletter: - The project sent 5 newsletters to 2,035 subscribers. Transfer Project Website: - There were 11,226 visitors to the website. On average, visitors explored 2.1 pages per session and spent over 2 minutes on the site. Most of the website visitors came from: USA, Tanzania, UK, Malawi, Ghana and Italy.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
